qas.question: Why is the Sumerian language usually thought of as a language isolate in linguistics?

answers.text: belongs to no known language family

qas.question: Akkadian's language can be traced to the Semitic branch of what languages?
What has been the result of attempts to connect Sumerian to other language groups?
In Sumerian, what are morphemes added together to create?

plausible_answers.text: it belongs to no known language family

qas.question: Why is Akkadian an isolate language?
What are added together to make words in analytic languages?
What language has been proven to proceed Sumerian?

context: The Sumerian language is generally regarded as a language isolate in linguistics because <b5_0>it <a0_0>belongs to no known language family<b5_0/><a0_0/>; Akkadian, by contrast, belongs to the Semitic branch of the <a1_0>Afroasiatic<a1_0/> languages. There have been many <a2_0>failed<a2_0/> attempts to connect Sumerian to other language groups. It is an agglutinative language; in other words, morphemes (<a3_0>"units of meaning"<a3_0/>) are added together to create <a4_0>words<a4_0/>, unlike analytic languages where <b6_0>morphemes<b6_0/> are purely added together to create sentences. Some authors have proposed that there may be evidence of a sub-stratum or add-stratum language for geographic features and various crafts and agricultural activities, called variously <b7_0>Proto-Euphratean or Proto Tigrean<b7_0/>, but this is disputed by others.
